results.title: Oral hygiene: Johnnie and the D.K. robot
results.creator_credit: Larkin Studios and Film Producers Guild
results.brief_description: The importance of brushing teeth before going to bed, told in a dream which involves a little boy, a trip into space, and a D.K. Robot. On the planet Yum-Yum where sweets grow on trees, the children lose their teeth until Johnnie introduces them to toothbrushes and toothpaste. Animation and live footage.

results.title: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit: British Information Services, James Archibald and Don Levy
results.brief_description: An impressionistic survey of the arts in Britain ranging from sculptors and painters at work to a display of Mary Quant fashions and vistas of modern architecture. The theatre is represented by excerpts from three plays staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company and there is a sequence from a new ballet by Sir Frederick Ashton. Some of the work of Henry Moore is seen as well as paintings by Francis Bacon. Includes a brief appearance by a very young Googie Withers.

results.title: Opus 65
results.creator_credit: Wallace Productions, Ford Motor Company, A V Curtice and John Taylor
results.brief_description: An attempt at discovering and expressing a relationship between music and a mechanical process on an abstract level. Richard Arnell was commissioned by the Ford Motor Company to compose a symphonic piece inspired by a visit to their factory. The scriptwriter then wrote a detailed scenario to fit the music, drawing a sketch of every set-up. The resulting film, following the scheme of the music, falls into three movements: The first, a general impression; the second, with the motive of Man versus Machine; the third, climaxing in the actual production of a car.

results.title: Options
results.creator_credit: Perspective Films, Jerry Aronson and Howard Sturges
results.brief_description: Believing that people want to feel, hear and become involved in art, the Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art, and its sister museums created “Options” - an exhibit meant to be touched and played with. It is a new approach to contemporary museums, involving more than just passive looking. The roving camera explores the reactions of the participants, and through the use of fast cuts, unusual angles and electronic music, the film becomes as involving an experience as the exhibit itself. Narrated by Ken Nordine.

results.title: Optical Toy, Anamorphosis, French Emperor Napoleon III,  Walter Frères 1865
results.brief_description: Constellation: The anamorphic drawing presents a distorted perspective of Napoleon III that is corrected when reflected on a circular surface. Napoleon III declared himself emperor of France in 1851, bringing the Second Republic to an end. William Kentridge’s anamorphic animation refers to Italy’s invasion of Ethiopia under Mussolini when 275,00 Ethiopians lost their lives. The title highlights the recurring nature of history.
results.title_for_label: Optical Toy, Anamorphosis, French Emperor Napoleon III, Walter Frères 1865
results.description: Anamorphic illusion hide their true subjects in distorted perspectives. When viewed with a viewing cylinder they reveal recognisable images, with some even made to unveil their images when viewed from the right vantage point. Anamorphic drawings helped establish perspective in paintings, photography and special effects, and they also influenced the development of Cinemascope and widescreen in film.

results.title: Optical jig borers at work
results.creator_credit: Montana Film Zurich and Societe Genevoise D'Instruments de Physique
results.brief_description: A documentary on precision milling and boring machines. Opens by telling us the story of how a group of people created the “Societe Genevoise D’Instruments de Physique”, a society formed to create a way to measure using unit measurements. We then travel into the future to see how the dividing machines they originally created are working now.

results.title: Operavox
results.creator_credit: Bare Boards Production, Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales), BBC Enterprises, BBC-TV, Christmas Film, Pizzaz Pictures, Glenn C. Holberton, Renat Zinnurov, John Cary, Sue Goffe, Naomi Jones, Mario Cavalli, Natalia Dabizha, Gary Hurst, Valeri Oganov, Barry Purves and Graham Ralph
results.brief_description: This television series from the United Kingdom combines traditional opera with various animation techniques. Contains six segments from the operas: Carmen, Barber of Seville, Turandot, Magic Flute, Rigoletto, Das Rheingold. Traditional puppet animation (by Natalia Dabizha) is used for the Barber of Seville (Rossini) applying a suitably comic tone to the excerpt. Mario Cavalli utilises live action footage, and then paints over the images for his animated segment from Carmen (Bizet). For Rigoletto (Verdi) the dark themes of the opera are ably evoked with stop action puppet animation by Barry J.C. Purves. Other animators include: Gary Hurst (Puccini’s Turandot), Valeri Oganov (Mozart’s The Magic Flute), and Graham Ralph (Wagner’s Das Rheingold). The musical performance is by the Welsh National Opera and features various singers in each segment. Barber of Seville: Donald Maxwell, Peter Bronder, Patricia Bardon (singers), Gareth Jones (conductor) ; Das Rheingold: Phillip Joll, Penelope Walker, Janice Watson (singers), David Seaman (conductor) ; Carmen: Jean Rigby, Adrian Thompson, Donald Maxwell (singers), Julian Smith (conductor) ; Turandot: Jane Eaglen, Edmund Barham, Janet Watson (singers), Wyn Davies (conductor) ; Rigletto: Jonathan Summers, Rosemary Joshua, Anthony Mee (singers), Wyn Davis (musical director) ; The Magic flute: Neill Archer, Alwyn Mellor, John Connell (singers), David Seaman (conductor). Some images of nudity and violence make this DVD unsuitable for young children.
